Re: License #: CI331000184
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Original Licensing Study Report for the above referenced facility. The
study has determined substantial compliance with applicable licensing statutes and
administrative rules. Therefore, an original license is issued.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Tyler Armstrong, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The Catholic Charities IEC Children’s Home (CCIEC) will be a private child caring
institution operating within a facility located on the main campus of the parent
organization in Lansing Charter Township. Upon arrival to the facility there is a
large parking lot with administrative and other service provision buildings next
door. When entering the facility there is a waiting area and a chapel. There is a
large hallway that acts as the main thoroughfare for the facility, with office spaces,
therapeutic and medical offices and a full kitchen. At the end of the hallway there
are four identical units with nine bedrooms apiece. Each unit has a common area
for grouping and recreation, a small kitchenette, storage and desk space for staff.
Youth will have their own bedrooms within the facility. The units are connected in
pairs with the ability for secured locks to prevent entry when necessary. There
are various recreation and self-care spaces inside the building as well as a full
gymnasium. The building also has a separate education wing with three
6

classroom spaces and one additional space to meet the educational needs of
youth.
An Environmental Health Inspection was approved as of 03/11/2025 resulting in
an “A” rating. A Fire Safety Inspection was completed on 04/09/2025 through the
Bureau of Fire Services with full approval provided. The Charter Township of
Lansing approved this property to be used in this capacity as of 05/24/2024. The
facility will have working cameras in multiple locations with the ability to record
and save video.
B. Program Description
The Catholic Charities IEC Children’s Home (CCIEC) is a private child caring
institution intended to provide residential services for two distinct programs. The
facility will provide a non-secure treatment residential setting for unaccompanied
refugee minors (URM). These youth will have verified undocumented immigration
statuses. The facility has made nine beds available for both male and female
youth between the ages of six and 17. The URM programming is intended to
provide education, independent living skills, mental health treatment, case
management and community integration to youth in the immigration system.
Referrals for potential placements will come from MDHHS or the Office of Global
Michigan.
CCIEC will also offer secure short term psychiatric residential treatment (PRTF) to
male and female youth aged six to 17, with 27 beds available. These youth will
be considered a person requiring treatment as defined by the Michigan Mental
Health Code. The PRTF programming is intended to stabilize and prepare youth
for reintegration into less restrictive environments. These youth will be provided
psychiatric and mental health treatment. Referrals will come from MDHHS and
other authorized sources.
Ineligible youth for both programs include those with a history of fire-setting,
severe aggression posing an active safety risk and medical needs requiring 24/7
skilled nursing care as well as acute psychiatric conditions requiring
hospitalization. The facility has provided policy & procedures that addresses the
separation of youth placed in the two separate programs with the facility. In
addition, separate requirements have been provided for the supervision of youth.
The URM youth will be provided with a supervision ratio of 1:8 during waking
hours and 1:12 during sleeping hours, and the corresponding ratios for PRTF
youth will be 1:4 and 1:7. The intended length of stay for both programs is three
to 12 months.
Newly placed youth in either program will receive orientation programming and
will learn about the highly structured daily schedules within the facility. The facility
has provided a behavior management curriculum that includes an approved
physical restraint model in Safety Care. CCIEC will not use seclusion as a
behavior management intervention in either program.
7

Medical and dental care for youth placed in the program will be provided by staff
within the parent organization. Catholic Charities IEC has new medical and dental
services that have been opened on site and will be available to youth placed.
Education programming will be differentiated between the two programs. URM
youth will attend school within the Lansing School District with English as a
Second Language services being made available. PRTF youth will be enrolled in
either the Lansing School District or an accredited private charter school,
Michigan Connections Academy. All youth’s educational programming will be
able to support special education accommodations and youth will earn credits
towards Michigan standards for graduation.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The facility has currently provided proposed compliance with all child caring
institution licensing rules that apply to their programming.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
original license be issued.
04/28/2025
